comments:
The first half of the course covers the principles and techniques of macromolecular
structure determination using X-ray crystallography. The second half of the
course covers extracting biological information from X-ray crystal structures with special
emphasis on using structures reported in the recent literature and presented by the
students.
Students enjoyed this course overall and reported learning a lot from it; however,
students’ chief complaint about it was that “there was far too much material to be covered
in such a short time,” and nearly every student who commented said that it would be
more appropriately taught as a full semester course. This had a negative impact on
students’ understandings of the concepts and material, and the course was described as
“rushed” and often “unclear.” A few students noted that there was too much emphasis on
the mathematics and physics of crystallography and not enough on its practical
applications. One student wished the course allowed for more “hands-on work in what it
is like to do crystallography today” to deepen students’ understanding of the calculations.
Students did not find the textbook helpful.
Students were generally complimentary of Professor Ronen, noting that his
“explanations were quite clear” and that he was always “really willing to help” students
in office hours. Again, students noted that his teaching suffered slightly due to the fact
that he had to rush through the vast amount of material covered by the course.
Students found this course difficult primarily because it “moved too quickly,”
with several students noting having “difficulty learning so much complicated information
in such a short amount of time.” Students did not feel they had ample time for practice
problems, and math concepts were sometimes unclear.
